text: good day to everybody first I'll give
you a quick snapshot of Suncorp we're a
diversified financial services company
operating and Australia and New Zealand
we're the fifth largest bank or the
largest general unsure the other piece
is that our primary mission in life and
purpose really is to price and manage
risk on behalf of our customers so our
frame of reference is that lots of
things go wrong and then when you
combine that with our overall business
model it's quite complex we have
multiple brands we have multiple
products with lots of systems different
technologies and when you combine
complexity with lots of things that go
wrong
it generates an awful lot of noise that
makes it difficult to see opportunity so
our question was how could we sift
through this noise and actually see the
opportunity and go on to great
achievement in history has lots of great
examples that demonstrate how people
overcome great big problems and there's
three common characteristics that I've
seen in a number number of these
examples and the first is there's no
substitute for a good congestion of
talent in the second is there typically
some technological achievement that's
that's overcome in third and maybe most
important is a leadership culture that
combines clarity of purpose we really
understand the problem you're gonna
solve along with passionate curiosity
where you look beyond your own frame of
reference and you overcome the obstacles
and you solve the problems so it's great
illustration of this and it deals with
the painting of cars now many of you may
not know the cars were actually painted
by hand up until the 1920s and it took
37 days to paint a car multiple points
of paint dry it and ready it for
delivery in the CEO of Dayton
engineering laboratories company which
became Delco his name is Charles
Kettering and he had solved many other
problems before he had invented the
electric starter for cars freon
refrigeration systems and he was aghast
at this and he challenged his engineers
that we've got to get better
this and they told him the most we could
ever get this down to 30 days so he
looked beyond his own frame of
references went many places and he
happened upon a jewelry store in New
York City and he found lacquered dishes
and he searched out the lacquer producer
was out of New Jersey and he connected
the lacquer producer with DuPont who was
providing the paint and they invented a
paint thin enough that car could be
spray-painted a glossy enamel finish and
dried in a few hours so he took that
example back to Dayton to his head of
engineer took a set of engineer out to
lunch and said I want you to tell me
again what's the best you can do and he
said well it's gonna be 30 days at that
same time he had some people go and
steal that engineer's car and spray
painted a lime green brought the
engineer back and said there's your car
and the engineers said well that's
impossible they said that's your problem
your job is to make the impossible
possible any wrote a brief in the
newspaper and it said something like
that preconception is a trap that
theories are just the summaries of our
past experiences and not the limits of
possibility and I have a saying at
Suncorp which is the windscreens a lot
bigger than the rear-view mirror why
should we be making our future judgments
based on our past decisions so the
question is could we use that
inspiration and and broaden our own
windscreen and look and see if we could
stretch that limit of possibility and
reimagine the IT landscape so my CIO
Matt Benjy know instead of
infrastructure and cloud services Terry
Powell they took it upon themselves to
say we're gonna go and make a very very
aggressive plan to move to the cloud and
then they very quickly realized quite
astute lean that when you start planning
of what to move you spend an equal
amount of time of what can't be done and
when you spend time talking about what
can't be done
that's waste so they made the very bold
and brilliant decision to say we're
going to move everything and we'll back
ourselves to have the talent and
leadership to figure out how to overcome
those obstacles when they do come up so
the one lesson that we learned out of
this is they very quickly hone did as
soon as they decided we're going to do
it
we're gonna we're going to we're going
to focus on what goes first and then how
to accelerate it and the lesson we
learned out of this is that the broader
your vision the clearer your purpose and
so the other thing that we had to do was
talk about well how do we actually
accelerate this we've got the technology
breakthroughs we've got Amazon's that's
a tic but we have to provide the talent
in the leadership to do this and
accelerate this so what we have going
for us is we have an absolutely
fantastic culture it's a battle-hardened
culture built on the last six years of
driving agile principles and practices
along with a very extensive graduating
and intern intake over the last six
years and some of the things that we
hold dear to us in terms of our
principles our clarity over certainty
course correction over perfection
self-directed teams over command and
control and then our agile practices
which are on continuous delivery DevOps
and distributed agile and our
distributed agile we have teams around
the world there in connected 24 by 7 by
Skype link TVs where the work is a sign
not on the role hierarchy therein but on
the skills and the gifts that they bring
to the party and we have a thing the
innovation day that we use to reset our
own aspirations we call it a FedEx day
in those days we copied it from a
company called Atlassian we didn't
invent it in in Australia and the
concept behind that days you can work
with whoever you want you can solve any
problem you want there's only two
constraints the first it's got to be
done in 24 hours so bring your sleeping
bags and your pillows the second is that
you have to have working software at the
end of the day so we thought what if we
use that day and oriented toward Amazon
and we did and so using Amazon
technology we had the FedEx day that
that we call an awesome API and we had
450 people from 10 locations in four
countries 42 teams that produce some
phenomenal solutions in the course of a
day and matwood from Amazon came down
was in the judging panel
and awarded the winners Kindles and the
lesson that we really learned out of
this is that we constantly understate
what our capabilities are to solve
problems and that the biggest constraint
is never the constraint of of time or
money it's generally the constraint of
thought and the key thing is how do we
reset our aspirations to get over over
the constraint of thought so finally so
we're where are we Andy challenged us
back at the end of July says you guys in
three months can you set up a virtual
private cloud virtual data center have
production applications in place by
November 1st and we took that challenge
we overcame all the technical hurdles to
do it we overcame the non technical
hurdles like legal and risk and security
and procurement and the net of it is on
October 30 as we went live with revenue
generating online applications as well
as our bi applications and data
streaming and we are now resetting our
own aspirations for what's next and in
the course of that what we were able to
do was create a very intimate emotional
bond with Amazon whether the the rising
tide is lifting both ships and my belief
is both companies are benefiting outside
of the commercial arrangement so my
final advice to all of you here is that
any problem can be solved so look
through your windscreen you know stretch
your limit of possibility and
opportunity and aim for success not
perfection because if you don't you'll
lose the opportunity to learn new things
in life thank you very much
you
